bestBHT.bht: On their journey, the two disciples communed and reasoned, exchanging views and feelings to weigh afresh the unfolding narrative. The risen Christ drew near, appearing in a different form, and their eyes were held, preventing recognition. In their conversation, they discussed the ignominious treatment Jesus endured and the reports they had heard from the women who claimed he had risen. Despite their wavering faith, their desire to obey God and embrace the truth found favor in the eyes of the Lord.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: communed and reasoned—exchanged views and feelings, weighing afresh all the facts"
drew near—coming up behind them as from Jerusalem"
eyes holden—Partly He was 'in another form' and partly there seems to have been an operation on their own vision
John Calvin: It was a proof of godliness that they endeavored to cherish their faith in Christ: though small and weak.
Their conversation had no other object than to employ their reverence for their Master as a shield against the offense of the cross.

When men are desirous to embrace the truth submissively, though they may waver on account of very small objections, and stop at slight difficulties, their holy desire to obey God finds favor in his sight.
Philip Schaff: Luke 24:14. And they were communing, etc. The substance of their conversation is evident from Luke 24:19-24.
Archibald T. Robertson: They communed (ωμιλουν). Imperfect active of ομιλεω...for preaching was at first largely conversational in style and not declamatory."
In the N.T. only here (and verse Luke 24:15) and Acts 20:11; Acts 24:26."
Our word homiletics is derived from this word.
John Gill: And they talked together,.... As they went along, on their journey..."
They very likely discoursed also, about the ignominious treatment he met with...
They might be talking together of what they had heard that morning from the women, that had been at the sepulchre of Christ, and reported that he was risen.

bhtAttempts.bht: As they journeyed, their hearts heavy with confusion and doubt, the two disciples exchanged views and feelings, weighing afresh all the facts that had transpired. Little did they know that the one who drew near to them was the risen Christ himself, but their eyes were held and they were blinded to his true form. Their conversation, like preaching in the early days of the Church, was largely conversational, as they sought to make sense of the events that had unfolded. They spoke of the ignominious treatment Jesus had endured, and of the reports they had heard from the women who claimed he had risen. It was a proof of their godliness that, though their faith was small and weak, they endeavored to cherish it and use it as a shield against the offense of the cross. In their desire to embrace the truth submissively, their holy desire to obey God found favor in his sight.

As they journeyed, the two disciples communed, exchanging views, reasoning, and weighing afresh the unfolding events. Their eyes were held, preventing them from recognizing the risen Christ who drew near. They discussed the ignominious treatment Jesus endured and heard reports from the women about his resurrection. Challenged by doubts, their desire to embrace the truth and obey God found favor. Despite small faith, they sought to cherish it as a shield against the offense of the cross.

On their journey, the two disciples communed and reasoned, exchanging views and feelings as they sought to make sense of the events that had transpired. Unbeknownst to them, the risen Christ drew near, appearing in a different form, and their eyes were held, preventing recognition. Their conversation centered around the ignominious treatment Jesus had endured, as well as reports they had heard from the women who claimed he had risen. Despite wavering faith, their holy desire to obey God and embrace the truth found favor in his sight.

As they journeyed, the two disciples communed and reasoned, exchanging views and feelings to weigh afresh the facts. The risen Christ drew near, in another form, and their eyes were held, preventing recognition. Their conversation centered around the ignominious treatment Jesus endured and reports from the women who claimed he had risen. Despite wavering faith, their desire to obey God and embrace the truth found favor.

On their journey, the two disciples communed and reasoned, exchanging views and feelings to weigh afresh the unfolding narrative. The risen Christ drew near, appearing in a different form, and their eyes were held, preventing recognition. In their conversation, they discussed the ignominious treatment Jesus endured and the reports they had heard from the women who claimed he had risen. Despite their wavering faith, their desire to obey God and embrace the truth found favor in the eyes of the Lord.
